dialogues.speaker: DOWNTOWN BOSTON
dialogues.text: As we open we see the inside of an enormous church. A you looking PRIEST in his mid-thirties is finishing the deliv of the LordВ’s Prayer. In the back of the church, in the pew, there are two who kneel on the cold, stone floor. They do not stand to sing, nor do they offer signs of pea when told, but they pray. They grip and rub their rosarie They mutter their words in Latin. CONNOR and MURPHY MacMANUS (mid-twenties) are shrouded in thick waist length navy P-coats, worn leather boots and t hungry clothes of the poor. The boys heads are shaved and they have facial hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissing young  priest) Thank you Father Macklepenny, for  coming all the way across town to be  our guest speaker today. I hope you  found our little parish to your  liking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macklepenny takes his seat on the alter along side the re priests of the church. The MacManus brothers suddenly sta as all others remain seated. Each church goer between the and the aisle shifts his/her position to allow the boys  passage, as if on command. The two turn and begin to stri for the alter, eyes down, determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thick Irish accent) They've never been like anyone else.  From the moment they were born, of  the same womb, on the same day, they  just had their own way, my boys did.  And I always knew that one day they  would do something of true greatness.  I just never expected they would  bring about such a... such a  reckoning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MacManus brothers are fraternal twins. As Annabelle  MacManus speaks, Macklepenny is taken aback as he scans t congregation amazed to find that he is the only one who t this out of the ordinary. The monsignor begins his sermon. Macklepenny rises to sto the boys from this disgraceful disturbance. The elder clergyman finds Macklepenny's arm, keeping him  seated while shaking his head. Macklepenny's confusion gi way to awe as he watches the brothers step onto the altar brush by the six seated priests, and approach the enormou crucifix. They both fall to their knees and kiss the feet of Christ They rise and as abruptly as they came, they turn and hea back down the aisle for the front door. They stop at the  rear of the church, turning to listen to the sermon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud, authoritative) ...and I am reminded of this holy  day of the sad story of Kitty  Geneviese. This poor soul cried out  time and time again for help but no  person answered her calls. Though  many saw, not one so much as called.  Her assailant wiped the bloody knife  off on her lifeless little body.  They watched as he simply walked  away. Nobody wanted to get involved.  Nobody wanted to take a stand... We  must fear evil men and deal with  them accordingly but what we must  truly guard against, what we must  fear most (beat) Is the indifference of good men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MacManuses turn and walk out the door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHURCH STEPS SUNNY MORNING
dialogues.text: The boys put on their dark glasses and pause at the top o the steps to light up their cigarettes. They both roll th cigarette butts along their tongues and screw them into t lips. In this unique way they light up, seemingly oblivio to their synchronicity and mimic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Irish accent) I do believe the Monsignor finally  got a point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Irish accent) Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy, wearing a white blood soaked smock and apron stan around the corner of the entrance to the loading dock. He grips a gigantic, bloody slab of meat and smirks. Connor  flips his cigarette out the loading dock and passes his  brother's hiding place. He notices the workers have stopp and are looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy slaps Connor square in the face with the bloody sl Connor's face is caked with blood as he stands stunned. H then leaps on Murphy, sending him into a pile of nearby  hamburger. He grabs a large cow tongue from a nearby heap and begins slapping Murphy in the face with it as they bo laugh and the workers cheer. Their boss, McGERKIN approaches with a very large woman. Her head is clean-shaven. The two are still laughing, out breath, they turn.

dialogues.text: This is a decrepit, illegal loft. The boys enter, hang th rosaries by the door and begin taking off their clothes. Connor sits naked on the couch and gently places a bag of ice on his crotch. Murphy stands naked in the open quanti shower. Murphy turns on the water and sticks his hand in stream.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONNOR AND MURPHY'S APT EARLY EVENING
dialogues.text: Connor, still seated, cracks open a Guinness and sips it  lovingly. The phone rings.

The  day your Da left us when you were  almost too young to remember, he  said the two of you would do me right  and make me proud, but he was wrong  and I got nothin' ta live for.

dialogues.text: Mom stands on the back stoop holding the door ajar with h hip. She holds the phone receiver up in her left hand and the gun directly next to it, in her right. She squeezes o a loud shot toward the heavens.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONNOR AND MURPHY'S APT EARLY EVENING
dialogues.text: As soon as the deafening sound pierces through the receiv Connor instinctively jumps up to a standing position. The bag of ice bursts as it hits the floor and spreads across it. He throws the receiver and covers his ears with both  hands. The phone then falls to the ground, skipping through the  cubes as the boys dive for it screaming. The two naked,  hysterical boys fumble for the phone, flailing on their  stomachs in the field of ice. They finally catch it and b put their ears to the receiver in panic. As they scream M intermittently, the pauses get longer and longer.

dialogues.text: Mom's got her hand covering her mouth, face red from hold back laughter, as she walks back into the house. She can  take it no longer and she bursts out with hearty guffaws.

dialogues.text: The boys are relieved, but angry.

dialogues.text: Smecker listens. The Chief is embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or, okay. Check this out. Say these  two don't even know the huge guy.  They're just staggerin' home from a  bar this morning, still all fucked  up from St. Patty's last night. So  they figure they'll take a short cut  down the alley and this big mother  fucker, he's just waitin'. And what  could be more perfect for strong arm  robbery? Two drunk guys all bandaged  up. They're already injured for Christ  sakes. He takes a blunt object and  whacks the guy with the bandage on  his head, right? Cause he's smart.  He knows the guy with the bandage on  his ass, he ain't going nowhere.  Matter of fact, this guy's probably  helping his friend with the rectal  problem along. They're limping around  like a couple of decrepit old broads.  So once this guy's out of the picture (denotes Vladdy) this poor asshole, he tries to run.  But look how far he gets fore the  huge bastard catches up with him.  Only a few yards. And what does he  do? He gets creative. He picks up a  sink and crushes the poor mother- fucker. Then, he ain't done yet. He  comes over here, jumps on this guy's  back and crushes him to death. (Vladdy) He steals their shit and beats it!  Thanks for comin' out! (beat) And look at this print...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greenly points out a large foot print on Vladdy's back. Some detectives nod in agreement. Smecker chuckles as he  shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one big fuckin' shoe!... and  think about it. Of all the ways to  kill a guy, crushin' him to death.  That's very particular. You don't  get many of those. I dunno. I feel  something big here. I wouldn't be  surprised if we see more of these  turning up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping into the  open) Brilliant. So now we got a Huge guy  theory and Serial crusher theory.  Top fucking notch. (to Greenly) What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Greenly. Who the fuck are  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker saunters up to Greely and pulls his I.D. out of t breast pocket of his sport coat and lets it hang. The lar light blue letters, F.B.I. can be easily seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's who the fuck I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the detectives seem disgruntled and look to the Chief for an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I gotta go by the numbers on  this one. I.D. just came back on  these guys. They've got connections  to the Russian mob. That makes it a  federal matter and Agent Smecker,  here, is heading up the investigation  with our full cooperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (transfixed on Greely) Why don't you get me a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CafГ© latte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twist of lemon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chief) Chief, what the fuck is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet-n-low!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greenly looks helplessly to the Chief, who simply nods. H storms off the scene, upset. Smecker turns his back on  everyone and puts earphones in. He reaches down and hits  play. The choir song "Agnus dei" overtakes. He begins to  investigate. He kneels at the bodies for a moment then st at the opposite brick wall. He picks up a piece of porcel and scrapes it with his thumb. He quickly cocks his head toward the sky and begins to ch as he says Jesus Christ, under his breath. He brushes som paraffin on each of the dead men's hands. Duffy and Dolly watch defiantly. They start to smile at one another as th collectively realize his homosexuality. He is slightly  effeminate buy not overly fey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly) Mitchell, Langley!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two uniformed officers approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find the manager of this building.  See if he has had any complaints of  water coming down in any apartments,  starting just this morning. If he's  not there, knock on every door  starting from the third floor up.  Langley, you take this building,  same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell and Langley exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaffey, Newman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two more uniforms approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chaffey) Look in the trash around their hands.  See if you can find me two bullet  casings. 45's, if my eye serves me  right. Don't disturb them. Mark them  as they lay. Newman, root through  this shit. (points to the mountain  of garbage) If this was a sink find me some metal  parts. Gimme a faucet or a drain  cover or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two begin their tasks. Chaffey finds a casing near  Checkov's hand, hidden under the edge of the pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it. It's a 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The homicide detectives are surprised as Chaffey looks fo the second shell. Smecker lights up a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief, could you get ballistics down  here and tell them they have to dig  a 45 slug out of a brick wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a bullet hole in the opposing and tattered w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and locate another that's been  fired through a dumpster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to another bullet hole at the dumpster's base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the best ballistics guy in the  world. He's mobile. Got all his stuff  right in the van. Can have him down  here in 10 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paraffin came up positive. And bullet  holes are usually a big clue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't find the second one, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look under the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obeys) Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker turns to detectives with a smirk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guy's ready for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was no gangland assassination.  Though creative, it was way too  sloppy. Something went wrong here.  This has personal written all over  it. Now, these men were crushed and  the first natural reaction the body  has to such trauma is to tense up.  So now the two shots fired here were  reflex rounds. These guys weren't  shooting at anything, but they were  just about to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent Smecker, (pointing to MacManus  building) This is all illegal loft housing so  there's no manager on the premises  but I found a lady on the fourth  floor said she's had water dripping  down on her whole place. Started  just this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourth floor huh? Then we're heading  to the fifth. Let's go up and see  just how right I am.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MACMANUS' APT. BUILDING FIRST FLOOR MORNING
dialogues.text: The detectives pile into the elevator, Smecker last. Gree has rejoined them. Smecker sips his latte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you thinkin' here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the detectives chant the affirmative. The doors close

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the doors open, all the detectives chorus their disbel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. You know how big a guy's  gotta be to do that? Fuckin' huge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker turns to Greenly in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Oooo. I might be wanting a bagel  with my coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker exits the elevator leaving the three silent detec with that thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dolly) I ain't getting him no fuckin' bagel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detectives exit the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: Smecker appears first, glancing in momentarily. The detec pile in behind him. They survey the situation in total aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Greenly) We'll start the ass kissing with  you.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MACMANUS' APT. BUILDING FRONT STEPS MORNING
dialogues.text: Smecker saunters out, detectives on his heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaches Smecker) Agent Smecker. I know this  neighborhood pretty good. There's a  bar called McGinty's down the block.  It's a good bet they were there last  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns to detectives) Good work, Mitchell. I'll check that  out myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duffy starts walking down the street. A REPORTER is hot o his heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Duffy. What the fuck happened  here? You owe me. This is the one I  want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go get a cup of coffee. You  ain't gonna fuckin' believe this  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker is standing on the front steps in front of unifor officers and homicide detectives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want A.P.B.'s put out. I want more  uniforms on the streets. One thing's  for sure, wherever these guys are  they're hurting.

dialogues.speaker: INT. EMERGENCY ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: A potent song takes our ears as The MacManus brothers sit the E.R. They have already received care. Their faces are beaten and there are bandages and dried blood in various  spots. Connor's injuries exceed Murphy's. They are both c in only their leather boots, boxer shorts and worn out ol bathrobes. Young kids wait for medical attention, as their knife wou bleed. Two nuns in the corner console a third, whose robe are ripped and face is beaten. A woman toward the end of hall is so badly beaten she is unrecognizable. As the song builds to a more harrowing chorus, a man ente His clothes suggest he's a pimp. He is not injured. He lo around as he stands, perturbed, at the end of the hall. He reaches over and grabs the beat up woman by the hair a begins to drag her out. She is kicking and screaming from the floor, grabbing at his wrists as he hauls her away. (Slo-mo) The boys, instantly furious, stand and begin to toward the action, but Connor's legs give out on him and falls to the floor. Connor, still trying to go after the  pimp, crawls towards him. Murphy helps his brother to his chair and hold him tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Just calm down. Take it easy.  He'll have his day. He'll have his (turns) FUCKIN' DAY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music fades.

dialogues.speaker: INT EMERGENCY ROOM DAY FEW MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: An old Irishman enters the E.R. DOC (70 yrs.) has a serio facial twitch and is prone to blinking uncontrollably. He has a mild stutter. He also has Tourette's Syndrome and i apt to yell his two chosen swear words every now and then first fuck! and after a slight pause, ass! He rushes up a they stand to greet him. Murphy holds Connor up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for comin', Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Irish accent, squeaky  voice) J-Jesus. What the fuck happened? Are  ya b-boys all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An F.B.I. agent came by the bar. He  left me his c-c, he left me his c-c,  he left me this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands them a card with Smecker's name on it. They surv it with interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extremely loud) Fuck!..........Ass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the E.R. looks at Doc in shock. Connor and Mu don't even avert their eyes from the card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to turn ourselves in. It  was self defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y-y-yeah that's what he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the fuck's he know that? We  haven't spoken to anyone yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know. He didn't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys look puzzled. Murphy helps Connor down to his se

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen Doc, we need a favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A-anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy hands Doc a partially filled garbage bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold this shit for us, Doc. We'll be  comin back for it when we get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc exits, say one more "Fuck,...Ass", on the way out.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOSTON POLICE STATION PRECINCT OFFICE DAY
dialogues.text: The station is abuzz with the story. Connor and Murphy's  names are on all tongues. A legend starts. Every availabl officer is in the room along with the homicide detectives Smecker walks right down the middle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, I'd like to thank  whichever one of you donut munching,  barrel-assed dip-shits leaked this  to the press. That's just what we  need now, some sensational story in  the papers making these guys out to  be super heroes, triumphing over  evil. And let me squash the rumors  now. These two aren't heroes. (rolls his eyes) They are two ordinary men who were  put in an extraordinary situation  and they just happened to come out  on top. Yes, nothing from our far  reaching computer system has turned  up jack shit on these two. All we  know is what we found out from their  neighbors. And the general consensus  is that they're... angels. (pause) But angels don't kill and we got two  bodies in the morgue that look like  they've been...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker looks to Greenly. Dripping with sarcasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...serial crushed by a huge fuckin'  guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the cops and homicide detectives laugh and chide  Greenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are these me considered armed and  dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not armed. If they had guns,  they'd have used them. But dangerous?  Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think they're  dangerous? They were just protecting  each other.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOSTON POLICE STATION STEPS DAY
dialogues.text: The two are limping up the precinct stairs. Connor is dra over Murphy who helps his brother along, they are still  attired as in the E.R.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, look! I'm not saying one way  or the other. Just be careful and go  by the protocol on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any tips on where these guys may be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Officer Mitchell) Any word back from the E.R.s?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No help at all. Swamped from St.  Patty's. Packed with drunk, bloody  Irish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just hit the bricks nice and hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grunt police work is going to bring this one in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking loudly) These guys are miles away by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers quietly enter in the back of the room. All t officers are seated with their backs to them. Smecker and the brothers make eye contact. He knows who they are. The don't interrupt Greenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you want to beat your head  against a wall, then here's what you  look for. These guys are scared like  two little bunny rabbits. Anything  in a uniform or flashing blue lights  will spook them. So the only thing  we can do is put a potato on a string  and drag it through South Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is light chuckling from the police at this crack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud) You'd probably have better luck with  a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone turns and looks.

dialogues.speaker: INT. INTERROGATION ROOM BOSTON POLICE STATION LATER
dialogues.text: The boys sit in two chairs at a plain table with a record device on it. They are very serious and alert. Mitchell e with coffee for them. He shakes their hands and says he r respects what they did. Surprised, they thank him. Chaffe enters with donuts and a repeat performance of respect. S officers start to gather around the interrogation room do

dialogues.speaker: INT. INTERROGATION ROOM BOSTON POLICE STATION DAY LATER
dialogues.text: There are at least 20 officers and detectives packed in t tiny room. The MacManus' visit with the excited cops. All are in high spirits. The room is loud as Smecker walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is this!? This isn't a  fuckin' tea party. Get out! Only  thing I want in here is them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all file out. Smecker and the boys look each other o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This conversation is going to be  recorded. Just answer to the best of  your knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker reaches for the record button. Murphy puts out hi hand to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politely) Excuse me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy turns to his brother and speaks in Latin, in hushe tones. It is subtitled in English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What do we tell him about the guns  and money?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "We just got up and left. Bum musta  rolled them before the police got  there."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Smecker) Okay. We're ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker in intrigued with this tiny display. He hits the  record button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys are not under oath, here. I  am assuming you knew these two guys  from before, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We... met them last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had some pretty interesting  bandages. Know anything about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK. INT MCGINTY'S PUB NIGHT ST. PATRICK'S DAY
dialogues.text: McGinty's's is packed to the walls with drunken Irish. A of faces are recognizable from Noland's Meat. Connor is i front of the bar. He and Doc are staring at each other as waiting for one man to give in. Connor has his arms acros the chests of Murphy and some friends, holding them in pl They are interested in the competition. PRESENTLY...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (presently, imitating  Doc's voice) Would someone please come over here  and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: me up the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone falls down laughing. Doc is angry and starts thr ice at them. DAVID DELLA ROCCO makes his way through the  crowd. Rocco is thirty-two years old. He has shoulder-len dark hair and a full beard and mustache that wrap around big smile. He charges up to the bar and yells to Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Fuck! Ass! Get me a beer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This sends everyone even further into laughter. Doc throw two huge fists full of ice at him. He backs away laughing The boys get up off the floor and have a huge group hug w Rocco as they all scream each others names. They all laugh and commence drinking.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MCGINTY'S PUB NIGHT
dialogues.text: The bar is trashed. It's mostly empty now except for the  brothers, Rocco, Doc and four friends. Everyone is very d including Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to connect  with Connor) ...It's not that I'm homophobic. I'm  just afraid of faggots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connor pauses then bursts out laughing. Doc calls everyon to gather round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got some bad news. Looks like I'm  gonna have ta close d-down the bar.  The Russians have been buying up  buildings all over town, including  this one... Fuck!... Ass! And they're  not letting me renew my lease. I got  'til the end of the week to come up  with 26,000 dollars, or they take  the place. I left them a note telling  them not to show their faces t- tonight. They been pressuring me ta  close and take the last few days ta  get all my shit outta here but it's  my right to stay open ta the last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pause as everyone absorbs. They are upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me talk to my boss, may I can...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is cut off by everyone who obviously opposes Mafia  involvement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L-l-listen I don't want anyone ta  know until the last possible moment.  So you guys keep your traps shut. ya  know what they say; People in glass  houses sink ships.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone has quizzical looks on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know Doc, I gotta get you a, a,  like a proverb book or something.  This mix and match shit's gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Doc) A p-penny saved is worth two in the  bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Doc) Don't c-cross the road if ya can't  get out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs heartily. Just then, three large Russians suits enter. The obvious leader, CHECKOV, stands in front with VLADDY behind one of Checkov's shoulders, with anoth guy behind the other shoulder. They mean business. The  laughter fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thick Russian accent) I am Ivan Checkov. You will be closing  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a long pause) This is McCoy... we find Spock and  we got enough for an away team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs. Ivan is angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, how extraordinary. A bunch of  Irishmen... and they are being drunken  idiots. You are killing the  stereotype. I'm in no mood for  discussion. (points to Doc) You! You stay. The rest of you go  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you make like a tree and  get the fuck outta here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The locals roll their eyes at Doc's blunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down, Doc. I'm sure they're  reasonable fellows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Murphy each grab a Guinness and a shot of Hennesse and they approach the Russians with the peace offering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen fellas, Y'know he's got 'til  this week's end. Ya don't have ta be  hard asses, do ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's St. Patty's day. Everyone's  Irish tonight. Now, why don't ya  pull up a stool and have a drink  with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You insult me. I would never drink  that sewage. Especially with you  people. You are fools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checkov slaps the beer to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is no game! If you won't go, we  will make you go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys look at each other, remembering what Mom said. They still hold the shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If ya want a fight, you can see you're  outnumbered. We're trying ta be civil  here, so I suggest you take our offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make the offers, ass-hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocco pushes off the bar. He's had enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing between the  two brothers) Hey, there Boris. What would you say  if I told you that your pinko, commie  mother sucked so much dick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wham! Ivan punches him in the face. He is quickly down an out. Connor and Murphy's faces turn to stone as they spea the next few lines in flawless fluent Russian with Englis subtitles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Now, that wasn't too polite, was  it?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm afraid we can't let that one  go, Ivan."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checkov is completely taken aback. All the Irish are fair impressed as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think Ma would mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They clink the glasses together, throw back the Hennessey ball up the thick glasses in their fists, drop to one kne and both deliver a devastating blow to each of Checkov's  quads. Murphy on the left, Connor on the right. He's down for the count, writhing on the floor. The boy's each take a Russian guy and start fighting as t others start kicking and spitting on Checkov. This is a b brawl, lots of punches don't connect. Connor dismantles h man quickly. Murphy is still fighting as all the Irish tr to jump in and help Murphy but Connor goes into psycho mo pushing them all back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the boy go. He knows what the  fuck he's doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all back off and start to cheer him on. Murphy and V are ripping each other apart. Vladdy backs him against a  wall and pulls back, exhausted, for one good punch. Murph reaches up behind his head with both hands and pulls two  bottles of wine from a wall rack. He swings them toward e other with Vladdy's head as the mid-point. The bottles  haphazardly connect, one on each side of his head. He cru to the ground in an explosion of glass and wine. There is shock and silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicely done, boy!

dialogues.speaker: INT. MCGINTY'S PUB NIGHT A FEW MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: They have Ivan Checkov tied down to the bar on his stomac Connor stands with an unlit cigarette dangling from his l next to Ivan. He pours Hennessey all over Checkov's butto They all cheer. Ivan's face is battered as Rocco wakes an approaches. He punches Checkov in the face in complete ra Two friends subdue him as all chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, like my fine brother says, on  St. Patty's everyone's Irish. And  this piece of shit is about to be  initiated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they cheer, Connor lights up his smoke and tosses the  match on Ivan's butt. The Hennessey is instantly ablaze and Checkov is screamin and wiggling in horror. Some just stand there stunned, bu most of the remaining onlookers leap to Ivan's aid. They  furiously pat him out and turn on Connor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are ya tryin' ta kill him, ya fuck?

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONNOR AND MURPHY'S APT EARLY NEXT MORNING
dialogues.text: Connor and Murphy, fairly beat up, sit up on their beds. They wear tattered bathrobes and boxer shorts. They put t feet down into their leather boots. The boys examine the  extent of one another's injuries and reflect on their  hangovers. They both laugh and grab their heads in pain. Boom! The door breaks open and in hobbles Checkov and Vla guns drawn. Checkov is all beat up and the ass of his pan is burnt out. A bulky bandage covers his buttocks. Vladdy has a large bandage around his head. The boys stand in  surprise. Ivan smashes Connor in the forehead with his gun, sending blood gushing down his face as he falls to the floor. Mur helplessly yells his brother's name as he is brought to h knees by Vladdy. Ivan positions Connor on his knees befor the toilet, which is open to the room. Checkov puts his f on Connor's head and proceeds, as he struggles, to hand c him to the old toilet. So now Connor is bleeding and hugg the commode with his hands cuffed behind the bowl base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost whispering) I was going to kill you. But I'm  not... I'm going to kill your brother.  I'm going to take him down to the  dumpster and I'm going to shoot him  in the head. Then I'm going to throw  his dead body in the garbage. (looks at this watch) Trash guys are coming in 10 minutes,  gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checkov walks towards the door and says "let's go" to Vla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just a bar fight. You guys  are fuckin' pussies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vladdy pulls him to his feet and leads him away following Checkov. Connor, blood running from his face, listens to absolute  silence for just a moment. Suddenly his face reads the gr of the situation. In a split second he turns into an anim He's yelling, pulling, tugging and growling. His body is a whirlwind of motion. The skin on his wrists bleeds profusely.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALLEY MORNING
dialogues.text: Vladdy and Checkov lead Murphy out back into the alley. Murphy is on his knees next to the dumpster. Checkov has gun to the boy's head. He acts like he's going to pull th trigger, but he stops. Vladdy is standing twenty feet awa with his back to them keeping a look out, gun in hand.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONNOR AND MURPHY'S APT. MORNING
dialogues.text: Connor becomes so venomous, that he pulls the entire toil right out of the floor.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TO EXT. MACMANUS' TENEMENT LOADING DOORS MORNING
dialogues.text: (slo-mo) Connor steps out onto the sill of the huge, open loading doors. He is five stories up. His muscles ripple  with the weight of the toilet. His face is barbaric.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALLEY MORNING
dialogues.text: From his kneeling position, Murphy can see his brother pe 50 feet overhead. He does not let his face betray him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope your conscience is clear,  Irishman.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MACMANUS' TENEMENT LOADING DOORS MORNING
dialogues.text: (slo-mo) Connor bends his knees and heaves the toilet upw and swings one arm directly beneath it. He is no longer  tethered around the basin. He holds it at a cocked angle. The heavy porcelain tank cover slips off the toilet. He tosses the toilet in a left and outwardly trajectory,  then he jumps off the sill to the right. He is sailing th the air about twenty feet behind, and to the right of the toilet, cuffed hands above his head, robe up like a cape  behind him. Murphy screams

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALLEY MORNING
dialogues.text: (slo-mo) Checkov begins to laugh heartily. The tank top l pristinely on a garbage bag just behind Murphy. Ivan's lo turns to one of terror. Bam! He is crushed by the toilet. Boom! His gun goes off, punching a hole in the dumpster n the bottom. Vladdy hears the bang and crouches as he turn to see a wave of tiny porcelain bits. Connor lands squarely on Vladdy's back. His gun discharge firing a hole in the brick of the opposing wall. He is  savagely crushed against the ground. Connor bounces off a hits the wall, landing in the garbage completely unconsci Murphy takes his hands from his head. There is dead silen He runs to his brother, pulls him from the trash and chec his vital signs. He seems okay. Vladdy, still alive, slow crawls for his gun, inadvertently covering his own bullet casing. Murphy goes over, picks up the tank cover and clu the man to death with two hard and fast blows, then throw it up and behind him. It lands in the dumpster with a  resonating boom. Murphy quickly takes everything from the scene; guns, mon wallets, watches and a pager. He shoves it in a garbage b and throws Connor over his shoulder and runs out of the a

dialogues.speaker: ROOM AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Smecker stares astounded at Connor and Murphy. The boys  examine Smecker for a reaction. He slowly builds to a chu The brothers join in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gathering himself) So, how is it that you guys are fluent  in Russian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We paid attention in school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know any other languages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye. Our mother insisted on it.  French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy speaks flawless French with subtitles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subtitled) How do you think he figured all this  out without talking to us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Italian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connor speaks flawless Italian with subtitles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subtitled) I have no idea. Maybe someone saw  and talked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: German. (subtitled) Not in our neighborhood, man. A  hundred percent Irish. No one talks  to cops. Period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spanish. (subtitled) Then I guess he's just real... real  good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you guys doing working at a  fucking meat packing plant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers laugh. Chaffey enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Agent Smecker, we have a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The press is everywhere outside.  They're going nuts for these guys.  What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not being charged. It's up to  you. Do you want to talk to them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No pictures, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we could try the bag over the  head thing. Walk you right out the  front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our mother can see through bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, she can.  (beat) Any way we can stay here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, we have an empty holding cell,  They can... can they stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we'll have to check with your  mother, but it's ok with me if your  friends sleep over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all chuckle. Chaffey is embarrassed. Smecker stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to feed the dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a nice guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy speaks with the characteristic gay man's lingering "S".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOSTON POLICE STATION FRONT STEPS EARLY EVENING
dialogues.text: The police chief is standing on the front steps of the po station making a statement to the ravenous press: cameras and pushy reporters. Agent Smecker stands slightly behind him. Rocco stands amidst the sea of reporters as the chief beg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our official statement. The  MacManus brothers are not being  charged with a crime. It was a clean- cut case of self defense. We have  thanked them for their cooperation  and we thank you, the media, for  your tireless pursuit of the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The press is ablaze with questions. Smecker turns and wal down the precinct steps, passing Rocco, who carries a bun of folded clothes, and heads for the police station. Smec glances in Rocco's direction, barely noticing the man who has already passed him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MACMANUS' CELLS EARLY EVENING
dialogues.text: Rocco approaches the wide open cell as Chaffey and Mitche play cards with the brothers. Happy to see each other the boys and Rocco embrace. He hands them their clothes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MACMANUS' CELL NIGHT
dialogues.text: The boys are in a tight cell with a bed on each side. The are in their own clothes now. The brothers are fast aslee Suddenly, they lurch forward, throwing their chests out,  lips tight, still asleep. INT. POLICE STATION BATHROOM  NIGHT. An officer turns on the faucet of a sink and begins to wa his hands. We go down to the pipes beneath the porcelain  basin. An old leak seeps water through a crack in the flo

dialogues.speaker: INT. MACMANUS' CELL NIGHT
dialogues.text: A water leak starts on the ceiling. It drips faster and  faster. The water begins to follow a water damaged crack  along the ceiling. It slowly spreads in two directions. The brothers struggle for air in their sleep. Then slowly and at the same time, they each reach up one arm apiece a simultaneously curl their hands as if grabbing something. Their straining faces are brought from darkness to light they sit up quickly, face to the ceiling. Their eyes open wide and they each draw their first breat as drops of the creeping water land on their foreheads. They look at each other across the room in shock as the d of water still fall between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Destroy all that which is evil...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so that which is good may flourish

dialogues.speaker: INT. MANMANUS' CELL NEXT MORNING
dialogues.text: Murphy and Connor sleep. Murphy awakes to a beep, beep, b He removes Checkov's pager from the pocket of his bathrob

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRECINCT OFFICE MORNING
dialogues.text: Connor and Murphy enter as Greenly, Dolly, Duffy, Chaffey and Mitchell are having coffee and donuts. They greet eac other warmly. Connor grabs a pen and walks to the hallway

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We would be honored, sir, if you  would join us peasants, in a donut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duffy hands Murphy a jelly donut and a cup of coffee as D spreads a copy of the Boston Globe in front of Murphy. Th headlines read "The Saints of South Boston." All the  detectives chuckle as Murphy is momentarily absorbed. He  takes the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saints?   (beat) I will not accept this pizzle until  my feet have been properly anointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRECINCT OFFICE MORNING
dialogues.text: Connor cradles the receiver of a pay phone between his ch and shoulder. He pockets the pager. As the phone rings, h readies his pen. The other end of the line picks up and a thick Russian accent instantly begins speaking. Connor  responds by speaking a few words in Russian before he rea it's a recorded message. He begins writing. He hangs up t phone and smiles as he lights up a cigarette. INT. POPPA JOE YAKAVETTA'S OFFICE  DAY. A.K.A. THE JOKE. Rocco, still sporting a shiner, enters an office. There a papers everywhere and it is a cluttered mess of telephone filing cabinets, lamps and chairs. Rocco clutches a brown paper bag as if it is made of gold. POPPA JOE YAKAVETTA,  Rocco's boss, is on the phone. He is in his late forties. He's always comfortably dressed; sleeves rolled up, colla unbuttoned. VINCENZO LIPAZZI swaggers across the office to Rocco. He in his late thirties. He goes out of his way to look like Elvis; open shirt, gold chains and medallions. He is  overweight and has a bouffant hairdo, accompanied by Elvi shades. Vincenzo flips a half dollar in his hand constant Rocco and Vincenzo hate each other. Yakavetta talks on th phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hushed) Well, it's the funny man. Give it  here, package boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit defiant) Joey Bevo said it was important.  Said I had to give it to him myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snatching the package) Gimme the fuckin' thing. Now sit the  fuck down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocco obeys like an angry child. Vincenzo puts it in fron of Yakavetta. He sits on a filing cabinet and flips his c Vincenzo giggles and whispers as he pokes fun at Rocco. The two of them resemble kids behind the teacher's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hushed) I'm Rocco. I'm the funny man. Heee  Hee. I'm so fuckin' funny. Hee Hee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you Vincenzo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hushed) Tell me a joke funny man. Hee Hee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I caught your show down at the velvet  room at the Holiday Inn, loved it  when you busted into Viva Las Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincenzo's face drops he gets up and starts walking towar Rocco. Roc points at him from a seated position. He's sca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, hey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Yakavetta jumps to a standing position. He yells

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you! I could snap my fingers  and have you dead in four hours,  rotting in a truck off of Boyleston!  You insignificant little fuck! I  always get my fuckin' money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the phone down. Rocco and Vincenzo are shocked b try to look composed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' 90's are killin' me. I  shouldn't a done that. You're not  supposed to tell a guy you're gonna  kill him anymore. I gotta tip-toe  through the tulips with these  assholes. I prance. I'm a prancer.  It's what I do... sucked all the fun  right out of this job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he speaks he unwraps the wax paper in the bag. Rocco l over his shoulder. It's a sandwich. He's embarrassed. Vincenzo smirks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poppa Joe, you want me to go now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks, Rocco. See ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocco starts for the door. Vincenzo begins whispering in  Yakavetta's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Rocco, wait. Come back here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah boss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincenzo continues whispering for a few more seconds, lon enough for Rocco to see. Vincenzo's lips are tight. His t grind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always see you talking to the boys  and making them laugh. They always  come around telling me what a crack  up you are. What is it they call  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (totally intimidated) The... The funny man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The funny man. Well, I got a new job  for you, just for now. Roc, I'm having  a real shitty day. I'm depressed.  Tell me a funny story or a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified) Uh. Okay... um... you hear the one  about the, no fuck that one... uh...  oh! oh! Well... shit. Okay, there's  a white guy. He's walkin' along the  beach and he finds a, a pot, y'know  and ah, he rubs it and this genie  pops out. But this genie, he's a  ni... he's a black guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a nigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. And uh, he's pissed off. He  says, "Why you crackers always gotta  find my mother fuckin' pot? And he  tells him he's gonna grant all his  three wishes but he's gonna give all  the black guys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niggers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry! Sorry! All the niggers on the  planet get double what he wishes  for. "I'll take a million dollars,"  he says. Genie give it to him and  says every nigger on earth just got  two million. "I don't care gimme a  yacht." Poof there it is. (intimidated, losing  steam) E-every bl... every nigger just got  two yachts. Genie goes... (gives up) I'm sorry Poppa Joe. I can't. This  joke sucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yakavetta takes a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continue the joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deflated) He says, "What's your third wish?"  And the guys says, "I-I want you to  beat me half to death."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a long tense pause. Suddenly, Yakavetta throws hi head back and roars with laughter. Vincenzo joins in. Roc lets out a semi-audible sign of relief and gradually star laughing himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still in guffaw) Very good stuff, Rocco. Very good  stuff. Tell me another one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocco returns to terror. Yakavetta erupts again pointing Rocco.

dialogues.speaker: INT COMMON BOSTON HOME ANTEROOM TWILIGHT
dialogues.text: Connor and Murphy give a huge Irishman guns, money and go watches. He hands them two big black duffle bags and moti for them to help themselves as he counts the money. They  enter a well equipped arsenal. They are giddy as they go their first shopping spree. They toss in masks and gloves They toss in four identical black finished 9mm handguns w silencers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what we need, man?... some rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie Bronson's always got rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, these guys always got a lot of  rope strapped around em in the movies  and they always end up using it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you've lost it, haven't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. That's stupid. Name one thing  we're gonna need it for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know they just always need  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is all this "they" shit? This  ain't a movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connor pulls a large hunting knife from Murphy's bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right, Rambo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, get the stupid fuckin'  rope.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SMECKER'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Paul Smecker lies in bed with his young lover, Reuben (mi twenties). He has an innocent, feminine look and a GQ air about him. The two have just had sex and Reuben is far mo excited about it than Smecker. Reuben pants and gestures that it was a wonderful experie Smecker watches TV. Reuben reaches over and affectionately places a hand on  Smecker's chest. Paul tosses it off with indifference. Reuben has a pouty look. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh,huh.  (pause) Room number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reuben throws an arm over Smecker's abdomen and places hi head on Paul's bare chest as if to now force affection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a time of death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is visibly miffed with Reuben's sudden display. He tri to pull the arm away but Reuben holds tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) What's the body count?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker is annoyed. He slaps Reuben semi-gently once on h exposed cheek. Reuben closes his eyes and holds even tigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bites his lower lip in anger and smack Reuben again on the same cheek, hard. Reuben jumps to a sitting position  holding his cheek. He is shocked and hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be down there in a bit. Keep  the press out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. Immediately to Reuben, semi-angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I was just trying to cuddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuddle?...  (yelling) What a fag!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker saunters down the hall, his usual confident smile He is impeccably dressed in a brightly colored suit. Gree stands directly outside an open door at the hall's end. A steady flow of detectives and forensics filter in and out Smecker halts before Greenly and looks straight into his  eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intrigued) He's struck again, hasn't he, Greenly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you always disrespect me like  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Respect is earned, Greenly, never  given. Guys like you should have to  follow me around squabbling for the  scraps from my table.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PLAZA HOTEL SUITE LIVING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Smecker and Greenly walk into a large sunken living room  with high ceilings. There is a huge white shaped pit couc in the center with seven dead bodies draped across it. Al the bodies have been turned so they are either seated or their backs and bright new pennies have been place in the eyes. There is one corpse directly in the middle of the l room, making eight. This victim (THE FAT MAN) is overweig and is lying in debris made up of sheet rock and broken w which spreads thinly for a five foot radius around him. The victims' body positions are in a circle with the fat as the hub. Smecker is instantly engulfed. The regular  homicide detectives are on hand with their I.D.s hanging of their breast pockets. They see Smecker and back off. Duffy wears an especially loud tie. Smecker lights up a s He circles around and sees another body behind the couch, which makes nine. The victim is on his back, with pennies stuck in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many bodies, Greenly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still Dejected) Eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker's eyes widen as he turns to Greenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (catching himself) No! Shit! I didn't see that one.  Nine! Nine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker takes a beat. He addresses the detectives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Greenly's getting coffee,  anybody else want anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he walks to the  door) Shit! Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker surveys the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Duffy, got any theories to go  with that... tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks down) These guys were pros. I think they  were coming for one target, the fag  man, he was the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The what man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) The fat man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Freud was right. So you think  they came for the fag man, huh? And  what do you base this upon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was the only one done right. Two  in the back of the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the pennies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New hitman wants to leave his mark

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a possibility. Y'know you  Boston cops are perking up. That's  two sound theories in one day, neither  of which deal with abnormally sized  men.  (pause) Another possibility is that they  were placed there with religious  intent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Some cultures still put pennies  in the eyes of the dead, or silver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Greeks. The Italians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sicilians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the symbology there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker tosses the Idiot glance to Dolly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Symbology? Well, now that Duffy has  relinquished his King Bone Head crown  I see we have an heir to the throne.  I'm sure the word you were looking  for was symbolism. What's the  symbolism there? Let me explain it  to you. In Greek and Roman mythology  when you died you would have to pay  the toll to Charon, the boatman who  ferried you across to the gates of  judgment. This made sure the dead  came to atone for what they did during  their lives, Detective...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smecker looks at his I.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dollapoppaskalious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detectives are impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit. You're the first one that's  ever got that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside) Yeah, well... I'm an expert in name- ology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detectives chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PLAZA HOTEL SUITE LIVING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Smecker is chain smoking. His clothes appear unkempt. His eyes show emotion at every new found clue. The detectives watch closely. He is hunched over the body of the fat man probing his wounds with his gloved fingers. Greenly has r entered. He defiantly holds a cup of coffee but is too  intimidated to interrupt Smecker. He sets it down and fol his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen burns like these before.  They used silencers. Look at these  entry and exit wounds. They're  identical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands up and gives a lesson to the now eager detectiv He points his two index fingers to the back of his own sk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two bullets went in here, through  the top of the skull, criss-crossed  and exited through the eyeballs.  This one clue tells us three distinct  facts. Number one... Duffy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shot him at a downward angle. (makes connection) They put him on his knees.

dialogues.text: Excellent! Number two. Greenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh.  (thinking hard) Shit, I, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

No. Two men of similar height dropped  this guy down, each put some iron to  his head and boom! That's all she  fuckin' wrote!

He  wouldn't cock out his elbows, makes  no sense. Besides, you telling me  one guy came in here and killed eight  men with eight extremely well aimed  shots in just a few seconds? No way.  Had to be at least two.

dialogues.text: Smecker is now a complete mess. His hair is totally frazz He is sucking on cigarettes long and hard. His clothes ar completely disheveled.

That James  Bond shit never happens in real life.  Professionals don't do that. So we've  got this up here, which has novice  written all over it. And all this  down here that's simply a perfect  textbook assassination. So here's  our two possibilities. We either  have rank amateurs that got lucky or  consummate professionals that fucked  up.

dialogues.text: The detectives nod in agreement. They are now completely  taken in by Smecker's spell.

dialogues.text: Join me in a drink, gentlemen.

So, I  am going to make you privy to some  information that you would not  normally be. These men are all Russian  mob. Not like those two peons in the  alley the other day. These guys are  all syndicate bosses and underbosses.  I have a dossier on every man in  this room. Since the Iron Curtain  has gone down, the Russian syndicates  have started to come here. And in  the spirit of Glasnost the Soviets  have opened their borders to the  mafia. But the Italians, they're not  convinced that the grounds in mother  Russia are fertile enough for  organized crime yet. So they ain't  ready to commit. The Russians are  coming here anyway. They are  unwelcome. What we have here,  gentlemen, is possibly the beginning  of the first international mob war...  unless I've totally missed something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All their faces read the gravity of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, what is this going to look like  to those who do not know what I just  told you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna look like the bad guys  are killing each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And is there an American, shit is  there a man seated among us that  hasn't thought about it many times,  let's just put them all on an island,  give them guns and let them kill  each other. This is our wet dream  come true. You can expect federal  and local law enforcement to go only  deep enough to satisfy the law, then  bury it from here on out.

dialogues.text: So, what do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends. You either do your job  or get ethical.

dialogues.text: Rocco comes out of the bathroom. He storms out to his sma round, living room table at which the boys are seated. He wearing a white, polyester shirt with gold trim that is a uniform of some kind for perhaps a chain of restaurants. is unbuttoned all the way down and his white t-shirt is  hanging out. He is wearing a name tag that reads "Jaffar" He is upset. He slams down a chair across from the brothe who are sitting there cleaning guns and silencers. All th accouterments of death are sprawled before them. They are smoking as they carefully disassemble their firearms.

dialogues.text: This better be good.  (viciously ties his  hair back) Talk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SIDEWALK DOWNTOWN BOSTON NIGHT
dialogues.text: The boys are walking across Copley Square. Connor looks a the note he wrote at the police station. They stand on th sidewalk and light smokes. They are in their regular garb thick naval P-coats, jeans and leather boots. They each c a mid-sized, black, duffle bag. They are serious and busi like. They scan the Plaza Hotel from across the street. T elite exit and enter the hotel. Connor glances at his poc watch. It's 8:45.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PLAZA HOTEL ELEVATOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: They enter. They look ahead, stone-faced, as the elevator climbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator stops at the lobby level. Nine, well-dressed men enter. Their faces are not shown. The boys move to th back wall. One guy says something quickly to another in Russian. The other gives a one word Russian response. They boys look a each other. As the elevator climbs, their eyes focus. The door opens. As the men exit the elevator, each face i seen individually, all are victims from Smecker's crime s The elevator goes up half a floor. They hit the stop butt and rummage in their bags. They suit up; black gloves and black masks. They strap on four 9mm. pistols with silence in shoulder holsters, one under each arm. Connor takes a  large coil of black rope and drapes it around himself. He looks at Murphy and at the rope in his bag. Murphy is too excited to argue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your fucking rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts it on. They drop to their knees, making the sign the cross. Then, up through the ceiling they go.

dialogues.text: They stand on top of the elevator before a long air shaft

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) See. I told you there'd be a shaft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Just like on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They jump into the air shaft.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PLAZA HOTEL AIR SHAFT NIGHT
dialogues.text: They start crawling with Connor in front and Murphy behin

dialogues.speaker: INT. PLAZA HOTEL SUITE NIGHT
dialogues.text: The plump boss is standing in the middle of the sunken li room. His eight Russian comrades are around him seated on the U shaped pit couch. They speak Russian, but no subtitles ar seen. The fat man yells. He's mad about something.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PLAZA HOTEL AIR SHAFT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Connor is taking lots of random turns, left and right. He starting to look a bit confused.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PLAZA HOTEL SUITE NIGHT
dialogues.text: The fat man is really yelling at them now. He is screamin and pointing at each man. They seem to be taking it seriously.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PLAZA HOTEL AIR SHAFT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Their brows are drenched with sweat. Murphy crawls up nex to Connor. There is only enough room for the two to lie o their sides facing each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the fuck are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll find it. Just calm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, fuck you. This rope is bullshit.  I'm sweatin' my ass off draggin'  this stupid thing around. Must weigh  30 pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy takes off the rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're doing some serious shit here.  Now, get a hold of yourself, asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asshole!? I'm not the rope-totin'  Charlie Bronson wanna-be that's  getting' us lost!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sh, sh! Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connor grabs Murphy's shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys get into a close quarters battle. An occasional  insult is thrown as feet kick and fists fly. They begin t get tangled in their own rope. The seam of the duct break and a tangled mess of rope and MacManuses pour out.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PLAZA HOTEL SUITE NIGHT
dialogues.text: They crash through the ceiling right above the fat man's  head. The rope gets caught and slams the boys to a halt,  hanging them upside down, back to back about six feet abo the floor. They are turning in circles. The boss is balle up in the fetal position on the floor. The shocked Russia say only a word or two in panic before the MacManus broth react, reaching for their guns. The Russians start to rea for their guns. It's too late. The boys draw and fire as  they spin. Taking four shots apiece. There are eight dead Russians. Chests explode as they fal back on the couch in a loose circle. One victims is blast over the couch. They notice the fat man directly beneath them. Murphy gra his Rambo knife, reaches up and cuts the rope. They land a heap, scramble over to the doomed man and place him on knees. They each put a gun to the back of his head and re this prayer in perfect unison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And shepherds we shall be. For thee,  my Lord, for thee. Power hath  descended forth from thy hand that  our feet may swiftly carry out thy  command. So we shall flow a river  forth to thee and teeming with souls  shall it ever be. E nomini patri, et  Fili e spiritu sancti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the silenced pop from their guns we cut the sound an go to black and white. (Slo-mo) Choral music starts with  Latin script being read in the background. They take thei rosaries out. They slowly walk around, mumbling prayers a they care for the dead. They gently turn over the bodies  that were on their stomachs. They brush the hair back fro the victims faces. They place pennies in the eyes of al t corpses. When they finish their ritual, they pull off the masks and look at each other. They start to grin and look around. They work each other into a healthy chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up) That was some good fuckin' rope.

dialogues.text: They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was way easier than I thought.

dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.text: On TV ya always get that asshole  that jumps behind the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we're good man.

dialogues.text: Yes, we are.

dialogues.text: Just then, there's a knock at the door. They snap into ac They stand at each side of the double doors, looking thro the peepholes. They see Rocco on the other side dressed a hotel employee. He wears a polyester shirt with gold trim and a name tag that reads Jaffar. He has a good cart in f of him. They look at each other and grin. Murphy nods. As they op the door, Murphy grabs the food cart and pulls it in. Connor seizes the mortified Rocco and pulls him in, slamm the door shut behind him. They run, dragging him and then throw him in the midst of the bodies. They put their guns right in his face.

dialogues.text: Oh, God! Don't kill me! We're on the  same side! The boss musta sent you  in as back up, huh? Oh, shit, please!  I'm Rocco. I'm the funny man. (almost crying) They call me the funny fuckin' man!

dialogues.text: (attempting to hide  accent) Where's your gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chest pocket.  (they take it) Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a six-shooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hiding accent) Nine bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're good. What were you gonna  do? Laugh the last three to death,  funny man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poppa Joe said there was only two.  In and out. (trying to make friends) Boy, you guys sure did a good job.  You're good, huh? Cool masks. Where'd  you get them?

dialogues.text: Let's do him right here.

dialogues.text: Right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?! Fuckin'... what  the fuckin' fuck! Who the fuck, fucked  this fuckin'? fuck. How did you two  fuckin', fucks?......... FUCK!!!

dialogues.text: Certainly illustrates the diversity  of the word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing here?  What, huh!? WHAT? WHAT? WHAT? ANSWERS!  I WANT FUCKIN' ANSWERS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slaps his face) Get a hold of yourself, man.

dialogues.text: Rocco is silent and surprised. Murphy, also surprised, lo at Rocco. All is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, get a hold of yourself.

dialogues.text: Listen, we gotta get outta here now.  We'll take separate exits and meet  at Rocco's.

dialogues.text: Murphy puts the two suitcases in his duffle bag and the t brush by Rocco who is still unsatisfied with his explanat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO PRESENT INT. ROCCO'S APARTMENT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Rocco has removed his hotel jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody you think is evil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think that's a little  psycho? A little weird?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weird, huh?... Know what I think is  weird? Decent men with loving families  go home every day after work. They  turn on the news and see rapists,  murderers, and child molesters all  getting out of prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mafiosos getting caught with 20 kilos  and walkin' on bail the same day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little girls catchin' stray bullets  in their heads, playin' hopscotch in  their front yards. And everyone thinks  the same thing... Someone should  just go kill those motherfuckers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill em all. Admit it, even you've  thought about it.

dialogues.text: Rocco ponders this as the boys continue to clean their  weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys should be in every major  city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys chuckle. Rocco steadily works himself into a hum frenzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is some heavy shit. This is  like Lone Ranger-heavy man. Fuck it!  There's so much shit that pisses me  off. You guys should recruit 'cause  I am sick and fuckin' tired of walkin'  down the street waitin' for one of  these assholes to get me, y'know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Hallelujah, Jaffar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're not just talkin' mob guys.  You're talkin' anyone, right? Even  like pimps and drug dealers and all  that shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys look at each other and nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well fuck, you guys could do this  every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're like 7-Eleven. We ain't always  doing business, but we're always  open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicely put.

dialogues.text: The three are partying hard. There's a pizza surrounded b Guinness cans as they whoop it up, sitting at the round t Rocco wears one of the masks. They're all drunk. The hous cat is lounging on the table comfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fuckin' guys. You ruined me. I'm  fuckin' done. Permanent package boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says that? You could take credit  on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, fuck it. If you think about  it, it's all you can do really. You  can't tell him it was us. Go in  braggin' and shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Climb the corporate ladder, boy. Don  Rocco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck it! I'm doing it. I deserve it.  I've been working for those fat  bastards since I was in high school  and look at this place.

dialogues.text: The boys nod in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (working into a frenzy) They're fuckin' me man! Hey, they  can suck my pathetic little dick.  And I'll dip my nuts in marinara  just so the fat fucks can get a taste  of home while they're at it. That's  it, it's done, I'm doing it.

dialogues.text: Rocco slams his fist down on the table next to Murphy's g The gun goes off with a bang! and blows the lounging cat  right off the table. A softball-sized hole is blasted in wall as a large splatter of blood sprays the area surroun the hole. Everyone is in shock for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't fuckin' believe that just  happened!

dialogues.text: The three are passed out all over the apartment. Rocco  awakens. He stumbles past the wall with the large, round, pink stain on it. There is a crooked picture hanging in t middle of it. Rocco staggers to the kitchen and throws water in his fac over a sinkful of dirty dishes. Connor awakens, grabs his jacket and follows Rocco out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hung over) Donna's gonna be angry about her  cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. She's on every drug know to  man. She'd have sold that thing for  a dime bag. Screw her.  (beat) But I do kinda feel like an ass-hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles) You sound real remorseful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connor lights up two smokes and hands one to Rocco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't been around in weeks anyhow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Listen. Something's been bothering  me about last night.

dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... what if your boss knew how  many guys were supposed to be there...  in that room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about it man. Nine men, six  bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think they sold me out? No way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He probably knew you'd end up nailing  the fat guy, maybe one or two more,  but he had to know you weren't walking  out of there. Figure it out. Shooter's  dead on the scene. No in-depth  investigation. It'd slide right off  his back. 'Cause as much as I love  ya, you're not exactly Don Corleone.  What would he be losing? A thirty- five year old delivery boy?
